metadata.case_name: Stage Carriage Operators v. State of Uttar Pradesh
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 380 to 389, 391 to 399, 401, 429 and 431 to 434 of 1958

facts.text: Appellants have been carrying on business as stage carriage operators for a considerable number of years on different routes in Uttar Pradesh under valid permits issued under the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939, along with buses owned by Government.
U. P. Legislature passed U. P. Transport Services (Development) Act, 1955 (Act IX of 1955) after obtaining assent of President on April 23, 1955, published on April 24, 1955.
Under s. 3 of U. P. Act, Government issued notification dated May 17, 1955, directing that specified routes be exclusively served by stage carriages of Government, excluding private stage carriages.
On November 12, 1955, State Government published notification under s. 4 formulating scheme for routes including those of appellants.
Appellants received notices under s. 5 requiring them to file objections to scheme; objections heard by Board on January 2, 1956 (except Agra region adjourned to January 7, 1956).
Notification under s. 8 published in U. P. Gazette on June 23, 1956; on June 25, 1956, order sent to Agra operators prohibiting plying on routes and transferring permits.
Appellants filed writ petitions in Allahabad High Court on July 7, 1956, challenging U. P. Act and notifications.

In Civil Appeal No. 429/1958, appellant's renewal application rejected in 1953, appeal allowed September 6, 1956, permit renewed from November 1, 1953 to October 31, 1956; applied for renewal October 11, 1956, no action taken.
Appellants in certain appeals offered alternative routes, tentatively accepted but obtained stay and continued on old routes.
Allahabad High Court judgment dated December 19, 1956; Motor Vehicles Amendment Act, 1956 (100 of 1956) published December 31, 1956.
Supreme Court permitted new grounds on repugnancy with Central Act as pure question of law.
Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act, 1955 assented April 27, 1955, amending Art. 31.

legal_issues.text: Whether U. P. Act became void under Art. 254(1) due to repugnancy with Motor Vehicles Amendment Act, 1956.
Whether scheme framed under U. P. Act is an 'instrument' under s. 68B of Amendment Act, losing operative force post-1956 Act.
Whether U. P. Act offends Art. 31 (pre-Fourth Amendment) for lack of adequate compensation.
Whether doctrine of eclipse applies to post-Constitution laws infringing fundamental rights.
Effect of constitutional amendment removing limitation on legislative power on prior law made under limitation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Motor Vehicles Amendment Act, 1956 wholly repugnant to U. P. Act, making latter void under Art. 254(1); no valid law to prohibit business under Art. 19(1)(g).
Scheme is instrument within s. 68B of Amendment Act; provisions prevail over scheme post-1956 Act.
U. P. Act violates Art. 31 (pre-Fourth Amendment) as no adequate compensation for acquired interest in commercial undertaking.
In Appeal No. 429, no notice given before scheme approved; proceedings behind back.

respondent_arguments.text: Amendment of Constitution removing constitutional limitation validates prior Act made when power subject to limitation.
No repugnancy between Central Act and U. P. Act.

court_reasoning.text: Post-Constitution laws infringing fundamental rights under Art. 13(2) are void ab initio and still-born; doctrine of eclipse applies only to pre-Constitution laws.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Law made in contravention of Art. 13(2) is nullity from inception; no validation by subsequent constitutional amendment without re-enactment.

court_reasoning.text: U. P. Act validity tested under pre-Fourth Amendment Art. 31; s. 11 provides adequate compensation per Schedule I.
court_reasoning.key_observation: UP Act does not offend Art. 31 as stood before Fourth Amendment.

court_reasoning.text: Central Amendment Act, 1956 repugnant to U. P. Act for future schemes; but schemes framed before Central Act not destroyed; saved by s. 6 General Clauses Act even if repeal under Art. 254(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: U. P. Act did not become wholly void under Art. 254(1); continued valid supporting existing schemes.

court_reasoning.text: No repugnancy destroying prior schemes; Central Act prospective.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Schemes already framed under U. P. Act subsisting.

holdings.text: U. P. Act did not become wholly void under Art. 254(1) on passing of Central Act; continued valid supporting scheme already framed.
Even if repeal under Art. 254(2), s. 6 General Clauses Act saves prior scheme.
U. P. Act does not offend Art. 31 (pre-Fourth Amendment) as s. 11 provides adequate compensation.
Doctrine of eclipse inapplicable to post-Constitution laws infringing fundamental rights; such laws void ab initio.

outcome.summary: All appeals dismissed with costs. U. P. Act valid; schemes framed thereunder subsisting despite Central Amendment Act, 1956; provides adequate compensation under pre-Fourth Amendment Art. 31.

key_quotes.text: "A post-Constitution law may infringe either a fundamental right conferred on citizens only or a fundamental right conferred on any person... In the first case... the doctrine of eclipse... also applies to a post-Constitution law of this kind."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Das CJ on potential eclipse for post-Constitution laws re citizen rights

key_quotes.text: "The words 'any law' in that clause can only mean an Act passed or made factually, notwithstanding the prohibition. The result of such contravention is stated in that clause... the law made in spite of the prohibition is a still-born law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Subba Rao J on Art. 13(2): post-Constitution infringing laws void ab initio

key_quotes.text: "the U. P. Act did not, on the passing of the Motor Vehicles Amendment Act, 1956 become wholly void under Art. 254(1) of the Constitution but continued to be a valid and subsisting law supporting the scheme already framed under the U. P. Act"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Das CJ conclusions on repugnancy and scheme validity
